title: Deborah Mailman opens up about playing the lead in new drama Total Control
text:
She's a talented actress who is set to play the lead role in ABC's new drama Total Control.

But on Wednesday, Deborah Mailman revealed she was nervous about 'driving the arc from beginning to end' despite over two decades of experience.

Speaking to The Daily Telegraph, the 47-year-old said: 'I did feel a bit more pressure this time round as in if I didn't get it right, then the whole show goes to s*** pretty much.'

Scroll down for video

'I did feel more pressure than I've ever felt before': Deborah Mailman (pictured) has revealed that she was nervous about playing her first lead role in ABC's new drama Total Control

'I did feel more pressure than I've ever felt before but having said that I loved every second of being on set all day every day,' she added.

Deborah will play the role of a politician named Alex in the series and will fight for rights to improve conditions for her community.

She said the show will bring attention to issues including indigenous land rights in an 'interesting and entertaining way.'

The series was previously titled Black B**ch but was re-named after claims it was attempting to reclaim a racially charged insult.

Total Control will premiere Sunday October 13 on ABC and iview.

She said: 'I did feel a bit more pressure this time round as in if I didn't get it right, then the whole show goes to s*** pretty much' (pictured Deborah and co-star Rachel Griffiths)

Meanwhile, Deborah is a decorated Australian actress and has enjoyed a number of roles during her time in the industry.

She previously revealed that playing the character Cherie Butterfield on the Network Ten's Offspring has been one of her favourites.

Speaking to The Daily Telegraph, the actress praised the show for making her race an incidental element of her character.

Characters: Deborah (left) will play the role of a politician named Alex in the series alongside Rachael (right) who will play a prime minister

'I think a lot of indigenous actors want to see more of this in terms of casting and characters that aren't culturally specific,' Deborah said.

She added in reference to Cherie: 'It wasn't about being a blackfella. It was just a woman on the dating scene trying to balance life as it is.'

Deborah has also starred in Redfern Now: Promise Me and Mabo and The Secret Life of Us.
